Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Story: It was almost midnight when my phone buzzed with a frantic call from my friend, Mark. His car had broken down on the side of the highway, and he sounded scared, asking if I could come pick him up right away. I grabbed my keys, ready to rush out the door, when I heard muffled sobs from my sister’s room. She’d been having a rough week, and tonight was especially hard for her—she needed someone to talk to, someone to just sit with her. As her brother, I knew she counted on me to be there, especially when she was feeling this low. But Mark was stranded, alone and anxious, and I was the only person he trusted to call. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the desperate plea of my friend and the silent pain of my sister. Both needed me, both expected me to be there, and I felt the weight of letting one down no matter what I chose.
